movies.description: Bearing no relationship whatsoever to any of Arthur Conan Doyle's stories, this first in the 20th Century Fox detective series still features a nicely raveled mystery set in a perfect Victorian London fog.
movies.title: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes

movies.description: Contains most of the elements of a nice old house mystery, but at a scant 45 minutes running time this offering from Fox U.K. Studios is compressed beyond any ability to engage.
movies.title: After Dark

movies.description: Plenty of plot twists and some admirably spooky set designs ratchet up the chill level, and a healthy dose of comic relief turned in by Maude Eburne makes this an early standout of the genre.
movies.title: The Bat Whispers

movies.description: The publicity and artwork implies unnatural relations between ape and woman, or at least inter-species experimentation, but what you really get is a weak melodrama interspersing stock expeditionary footage of Borneo with back-lot cheesiness.
movies.title: The Beast of Borneo

movies.description: Warner Oland plays an effective heavy in this old-house mystery from RKO Radio Pictures, which features the relatively unknown Dorothy Wilson who was discovered in the studio secretarial pool.
movies.title: Before Dawn

movies.description: Bellamy makes a surprisingly convincing protagonist in this murder mystery which includes the all classic elements of an old-fashioned detective story: identity theft, out-of-wedlock childbirth, sexual blackmail and suicide.
movies.title: Before Midnight

movies.description: It's worth the price of admission just to get a load of Karloff affecting the clipped accent of an American gangster, and Van Sloan is chilling as the evil surgeon whose hands literally drip with innocent blood.
movies.title: Behind the Mask

movies.description: Note: I don't have this.
movies.title: The Benson Murder Case

movies.description: Basil Rathbone delivers an intriguing portrayal of detective Philo Vance, who's called on to solve one of those drawing-room mysteries wherein every suspect seems to get eliminated by virtue of the unassailable vindication of having been murdered.
movies.title: The Bishop Murder Case

movies.description: Detective Charlie Chan of the Honolulu police works a murder investigation where Lugosi is a prime suspect in this engaging effort which constitutes the earliest surviving Chan mystery.
movies.title: The Black Camel

movies.description: You have to wonder why Universal would release two completely unrelated movies both called The Black Cat within the span of seven years, especially when this first film is so vastly superior, starring as it does Lugosi and Karloff each at the top of his game, so to speak.
movies.title: The Black Cat

movies.description: Stilted acting, along with the dreaded comic relief (in the form of a blundering sheriff) ruin this so-called "Crime Club Production" from Universal Studios.
movies.title: The Black Doll

movies.description: Despite a sometimes erratic plotline, this overlooked tale of voodoo from Columbia evokes a genuinely eerie mood and delivers a few astoundingly effective shock scenes.
movies.title: Black Moon

movies.description: Despite the cornball pseudo-European costumes and dialog, this ostensibly 17th century period piece (with outdoor settings clearly filmed in the badlands of southern California) features a fine dual-role performance by Karloff.
movies.title: The Black Room

movies.description: James Whale's poignant, horrifying, hilarious masterpiece demonstrates his genius and surpasses the original as a cathartic, visionary tour de force.
movies.title: Bride of Frankenstein

movies.description: This first in a series of six shorts narrated by The Shadow has great atmospherics and is the only episode to feature the voice of Frank Readick from the original "Detective Story Hour" radio program on which the series is based.
movies.title: A Burglar to the Rescue (Short)
The Case of the Black Cat
The Case of the Curious Bride
The Case of the Lucky Legs
The Case of the Stuttering Bishop
The Case of the Velvet Claws

movies.description: Paul Lukas takes a stylish but unremarkable turn at playing amateur detective Philo Vance in this entry in MGM's series based on the popular crime novels by S.S. Van Dine.
movies.title: The Casino Murder Case

movies.description: Definitely a whole different tone in this Paramount remake versus the 1927 original, but the plot is pretty faithful and despite Bob Hope's hokey sense of humor there are some fairly effective creepy scenes.
movies.title: The Cat and the Canary

movies.description: An enthralling storyline and top notch visual effects separate this serial from the typical potboilers of the era, especially when punctuated by Bela's super-evil portrayal of Roxor the villain.
movies.title: Chandu the Magician (Serial)

movies.description: This massively cheesed-out exploitation piece from Pinnacle Productions combines elements of forbidden interracial romance with voodoo spiritualism, yet sells out its premise as cravenly as any post-code film from the major studios.
movies.title: Chloe

movies.description: Nicely combines aspects of an old-fashioned detective mystery with the more sordid elements typical of a Hollywood pre-code movie; all in a big-top setting with some refreshingly realist escapades on the trapeze.
movies.title: The Circus Queen Murder

movies.description: The last of Universal's series of shorts featuring the voice of The Shadow (as always, admonishing that crime does not pay) hinges on a soft-spoken circus dick who solves a murder that has the local cops crossed up.
movies.title: The Circus Show-Up (Short)

movies.description: This engaging dark drama from London's Gainsborough Studios showcases Claude Rains and Fay Wray when they were at the height of their popularity after "The Invisible Man" and "King Kong" made them household names.
movies.title: The Clairvoyant

movies.description: Like a lot of 1930s horror films, this Invincible Pictures vampire tale unfolds more as stagy melodrama, but the atmospherics are quite compelling thanks to village sets borrowed from Universal Studios.
movies.title: Condemned to Live

movies.description: Erich von Stroheim is magnificently menacing as the evil Dr. Crespi in this understated classic from Poverty Row stalwart Republic Pictures.
movies.title: The Crime of Dr. Crespi

movies.description: Well-executed murder mystery with touches of humor and unexpected developments; taking place in a Long Island mansion loaded with secret passages and a creepy old attic.
movies.title: The Crooked Circle

movies.description: Majestic Pictures released this confused little murder mystery which is beset by plot holes as cavernous as the creepy old theater where the action takes place, but Sam Hardy is hilarious as the loudmouthed, dimwitted cop.
movies.title: Curtain at Eight

movies.description: Here we have a well put-together murder mystery from Chesterfield pictures with just perhaps one twist too many at its resolution, and one ridiculous deduction too many by its sleuth.
movies.title: The Dark Hour

movies.description: Murder mystery with a nicely concealed villain and excellent character portrayals, with half the cast of Dracula getting upstaged by the hilarious portrayal of a studio boss by Alexander Carr.
movies.title: The Death Kiss
The Demon Barber of Fleet Street

movies.description: Lionel Barrymore rarely appeared in horror films, and his performance in this one is delightfully entertaining, especially when he dons the guise of an old woman to exact revenge against his enemies.
movies.title: The Devil Doll

movies.description: Stylistically a pleasingly bizarre thriller accentuated by the weird hues of the two-strip Technicolor process, but the mood is compromised by an off-putting wiseacre reporter and a plot heavily laden with non sequiturs.
movies.title: Doctor X

movies.description: A superb example of pre-code suggestiveness as well as expressionistic horror, this film features fine performances from both March and Hopkins, along with outstanding makeup effects on the transformed Mr. Hyde.
movies.title: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde

movies.description: The only thing more amazing than Lugosi's out-of-body performance is the fact that the finest horror movie ever made was filmed within 2 years of the advent of talking pictures.
movies.title: Dracula

movies.description: Van Helsing again plays an integral part in Universal's 1936 sequel to the original Dracula, and Holden turns in a nicely chilling performance as the villainess of the title.
movies.title: Dracula's Daughter

movies.description: Warren William is not much of a Philo Vance (or anything else for that matter), but the setting for this mystery is fantastically atmospheric, and the clues are surprisingly well laid-out.
movies.title: The Dragon Murder Case

movies.description: Warner Oland is supremely menacing in the role of Dr. Boris Karlov (don't ask), and Mischa Auer is perfect as his devoted henchman in this tale of sinister vengeance wrought with a sadistic relish.
movies.title: The Drums of Jeopardy

movies.description: The jungle thrills in this early talkie from Universal are abundant and effective, but the acting (except Renavent's sinister portrayal of the evil Prince Hashim), leaves much to be desired.
movies.title: East of Borneo

movies.description: This is an expressionist masterpiece from Germany with exquisite cinematography and a stunningly beautiful tragic heroine.
movies.title: Ferryman Maria

movies.description: Overall a pretty lame adventure offering from Imperial Productions, with a plot that goes nowhere and the kind of production values you'd expect from a film where a dog gets top billing.
movies.title: The Flaming Signal

movies.description: Frankenstein solidified Universal's place as the premier horror studio of the era, and stands as the definitive American take on the school of German Expressionism.
movies.title: Frankenstein

movies.description: Browning's second foray into the horror genre has a cast consisting largely of actual sideshow attractions, but is more remarkable for its portrayal of the tragic human drama the characters are caught up in.
movies.title: Freaks

movies.description: A forgettable Philo Vance portrayal by Edmund Lowe is complemented by a forgettable script in this perfunctory MGM mystery/comedy, which is actually not much of either.
movies.title: The Garden Murder Case

movies.description: It this really was based on "Edgar Wallace's Greatest Thriller", let's hope the novel held together better than screenplay, which suffers from an abundance of plot twists but is rescued somewhat by a certain Ms. Louise Henry.
movies.title: The Gaunt Stranger

movies.description: The unremarkableness of this cheapie from Invincible Pictures Corporation is attested to by the fact that it took me three tries on separate occassions to stay awake through the whole thing.
movies.title: The Ghost Walks

movies.description: How can you go wrong with a tale of an Egyptologist returning from the dead to wreak ghastly revenge upon those who stole the sacred jewel he himself had pilfered from an ancient tomb, especially when it stars Karloff and Thesiger?
movies.title: The Ghoul

movies.description: I can't bring myself to expend any energy writing a review of this movie.
movies.title: The Gorilla

movies.description: The focus in this murder mystery from Chesterfield Pictures is on character rather than atmosphere, and although it comes across as somewhat stagy, the dramatic twists of plot make it really a fine example of the type.
movies.title: Green Eyes

movies.description: Lionel Barrymore is terrific as the barrister who'll stop at nothing to ensure his daughter's happiness, and Kay Francis is icily beautiful in this tale of murder and revenge from MGM.
movies.title: Guilty Hands

movies.description: Succeeds in imparting a flavor of the Orient, with the action unfolding in Hong Kong and Macau, but aside from Hymer's the portrayals are fairly flat despite some suspenseful action sequences.
movies.title: Hong Kong Nights

movies.description: Twentieth Century Fox delivers everything you could ask for in a Sherlock Holmes mystery, including the magnificently atmospheric Dartmoor visage, and an ecstatically ambiguous turn by Atwill as the village doctor.
movies.title: The Hound of the Baskervilles

movies.description: This subpar entry in Universal's series of short films featuring The Shadow is hampered by a confused storyline and poorly-drawn characters.
movies.title: House of Mystery (Short)

movies.description: Charles Laughton is a very effective Quasimodo, and his makeup is nicely done, but in general this RKO production has a pompous and overblown feel that comes from striving too hard to interpret the societal context of Hugo's great novel.
movies.title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame

movies.description: From the opening scene with Claude Rains stumbling around in a blizzard, the desolation of H.G. Wells' story is depicted with chilling atmospherics and astonishing special effects.
movies.title: The Invisible Man

movies.description: In their movies Karloff and Lugosi seem to take turns playing the heavy, and this time it's Karloff delivering nicely as the demented scientist while Lugosi plays the kindly doctor in a surprisingly suspenseful Universal feature.
movies.title: The Invisible Ray

movies.description: Despite the misleading promotional copy in the poster, it's Charles Laughton's deliciously evil Dr. Moreau that dominates this film and lifts it beyond the typical horror adventure piece; although Kathleen Burke certainly does deliver quite a fetching turn as Lota the panther woman.
movies.title: Island of Lost Souls

movies.description: Charles Laughton and Leslie Banks make delightfully wicked villains, but surprisingly the direction is the weak link in this tale of treachery on the coast of Cornwall.
movies.title: Jamaica Inn

movies.description: William Powell is a natural at playing amateur detective Philo Vance, and in this well-paced mystery from Warner Brothers he displays much of the easy charm that later gained him such acclaim as The Thin Man.
movies.title: The Kennel Murder Case

movies.description: From the wondrous scenes on Skull Island to the pandemonium of terrified crowds in New York City, this epic maintains an allegorical sensibility that puts it really in a genre of its own.
movies.title: King Kong

movies.description: Director Whale takes full advantage of pre-code liberties to render a rousing and risque murder drama, with some especially delicious zingers delivered by Jean Dixon in the role of a saucy female attorney.
movies.title: The Kiss Before the Mirror

movies.description: Walter Huston turns in a gut-wrenching performance as Flint, the brutal, paraplegic despot of a remote outpost in equatorial Africa where he commits acts of unspeakable cruelty.
movies.title: Kongo

movies.description: Hitchcock's early Gainsborough mystery has an outstanding premise and countless fine performances by various character actors who deliver the well-chosen and clever dialog with gusto, but it's slightly marred by an implausible turn of events.
movies.title: The Lady Vanishes

movies.description: To all appearances the Forgotten Horrors compendium was not exaggerating when it reported that Boyd was "roaring drunk" during filming of the penultimate scene, and maybe I would have enjoyed this snoozefest more if I'd been hammered myself.
movies.title: The Lost City (Serial)

movies.description: The searingly convincing elements of danger that Capra weaves into this fantasy adventure tale lend the film a chilling tone that warrants its inclusion in any mystery/horror collection, despite its lack of the usual genre trappings.
movies.title: Lost Horizon

movies.description: This is a real gem from the obscure British studio Trafalgar Films, with Rathbone demonstrating his dramatic range to terrifying effect in the role of a demented sadist fixated on doing away with his bride.
movies.title: Love from a Stranger

movies.description: Lang's enthrallingly suspenseful German thriller approaches its gut-wrenching subject matter with both honesty and sensitivity, avoiding simple moral outrage in favor of a more enlightened, yet all-the-more terrifying, perspective.
movies.title: M

movies.description: Peter Lorre is downright amazing as crazy Dr. Gogol; in fact the cast is excellent all-around with Colin Clive and Frances Drake as star-crossed lovers, and the story resonates nicely until it devolves into the usual business explaining the proceedings with a convenient bit of hokum.
movies.title: Mad Love
The Man in the Iron Mask

movies.description: Karloff exacts revenge for his wrongful hanging in this mildly engaging effort from Columbia Pictures; helped along by Boris's artful portrayal of the sort of mad doctor role he seems to have been born to play.
movies.title: The Man They Could Not Hang

movies.description: Peter Lorre plays a supremely menacing villain, and the suspense is nicely maintained during the final act, although the plot does take a few illogical turns during the course of the film.
movies.title: The Man Who Knew Too Much

movies.description: Karloff the scientist goes off his nut when his work is questioned and cobbles together the usual scientific hokum to perform mind-transference for highly dubious ends.
movies.title: The Man Who Lived Again

movies.description: How many times can one man face "certain death" only to survive with nary a scratch and live to stage a hokily-choreographed fight sequence another day?
movies.title: Mandrake the Magician (Serial)

movies.description: This movie was clearly not intended for the mainstream 1930s audience with its scenes of gratuitous nudity and insinuation of sexual deviance; however, what're truly jaw-dropping are the incoherent plot and crazy dialog.
movies.title: Maniac

movies.description: An abundance of eerie atmosphere is what this creepfest delivers; however, the hugely promising buildup is undercut somewhat by a cop-out ending which attempts to explain the supernatural occurrences by way of more pedestrian motivations.
movies.title: Mark of the Vampire

movies.description: Karloff is perfect for the role of evil genius bent on locating the ancient relics of Genghis Kahn which will enable him to rule the world, and Myrna Loy sizzles as his seductress daughter.
movies.title: The Mask of Fu Manchu

movies.description: There's definitely a hokey element to this standard mystery vehicle from Mayfair Pictures, but at the same time there are moments of genuine eeriness throughout, and the climax (which takes place in a morgue) is surprisingly chilling.
movies.title: The Midnight Warning

movies.description: A gritty portrayal, well-turned by Warren William, of the hard-knock livelihood eeked out by a con man running a clairvoyance hustle, and the sad consequences for the woman who falls for him.
movies.title: The Mind Reader

movies.description: Crazy twists and turns galore punctuate this old-dark-house, reading-of-the-will mystery featuring a caged monkey in the basement who's supposed to be menacing but is only slightly less ridiculous than most of his brethren in innumerable thrillers of the era.
movies.title: The Monster Walks

movies.description: The production values and cast are outstanding in this MGM mystery which takes place during an opera staged at the Hollywood Bowl, but the story is somewhat jumbled due to continuity issues introduced during editing.
movies.title: Moonlight Murder

movies.description: Wilkie Collins' seminal detective novel is treated respectfully in this Monogram offering; however, the running time of just about an hour is nowhere near sufficient to do justice to the original story.
movies.title: The Moonstone

movies.description: Superbly choreographed chase scenes featuring Wray and McCrea fleeing from Leslie Banks' villain (positively brimming with malevolent glee), elevate this film to the realm of the classics.
movies.title: The Most Dangerous Game

movies.description: All atmosphere and not much suspense (it's hard to be terrified of a decrepit, shambling creature who could have been outrun by a tortoise); still, the Universal Studios production values ensure a worthwhile viewing experience.
movies.title: The Mummy

movies.description: This is a first-rate detective thriller from the Poverty Row production company Invincible Pictures, with a stalwart cast, nicely-paced direction by Frank Strayer, and a couple of truly horrific murders to boot.
movies.title: Murder at Glen Athol

movies.description: With a distinctly pre-code sensibility, this Paramount mystery features both first-rate musical numbers and a compelling, well-wrought storyline to boot.
movies.title: Murder at the Vanities

movies.description: Nice creepy atmosphere and a compelling premise, but ultimately the weight of the preposterous reasoning used to solve the crime does this mystery in.
movies.title: Murder by the Clock

movies.description: Precious little murder, and even less in the way of mystery, adorn this extremely tame gangster tale from Associated British Pictures.
movies.title: Murder in the Night

movies.description: Charles Ruggles is slightly less annoying than usual in this decent little mystery wherein the always-compelling Una Merkel is the target of a sinister plot of revenge.
movies.title: Murder in the Private Car

movies.description: Edna May Oliver brings her usual vivacity to this picture in what would be her final portrayal of sleuthing schoolteacher Hildegarde Withers; however, the writing and direction fail to quite live up to the high standards established by the previous entries in the series.
movies.title: Murder on a Honeymoon

movies.description: Despite some preposterous shenanigans, this is a rousing edition in RKO's Hildegarde Whithers detective series; with the intrigue taking place on Ms. Whithers' very home turf, where her schoolteacher colleague is shockingly murdered.
movies.title: Murder on the Blackboard

movies.description: This is one of those nosy reporter mysteries that constitute the Poverty Row production companies' bread and butter; nicely told but compromised by the all-too-common flaw of an overly-complicated solution marked by an utter disregard for credibility.
movies.title: Murder on the Campus

movies.description: Only tangentially related to Poe's story, but still with a promising outline tragically undercut by the ridiculous portrayal of the murderous brute alternately by a man in a gorilla-looking ape suit, and then by a real non-menacing chimpanzee about one-fourth the size.
movies.title: Murders in the Rue Morgue

movies.description: Atwill is bone-chilling as the evil Dr. Gorman who devises ever more sadistic ways to dispose of his enemies in this first-rate Paramount chiller whose only defect is the ever-annoying Charlie Ruggles.
movies.title: Murders in the Zoo

movies.description: Not to be confused with the Boris Karloff's detective James Lee Wong (also from Monogram), this Chinatown mystery has Lugosi playing bad guy Fu Wong and features the obligatory wisecracking reporter getting himself into one ridiculous jam after another.
movies.title: The Mysterious Mr. Wong

movies.description: The setting of a creepy old hunting lodge contributes a nice touch of atmosphere to what would otherwise be a run-of-the-mill mystery story treading the well-traveled path toward utter implausibility.
movies.title: Mystery House

movies.description: Universal does a bang-up job of interpreting Dickens' last, unfinished novel, and Claude Rains turns in a suitably over-the-top performance as the opium-ravaged villain stalking among the creepy sets made famous by the studio.
movies.title: The Mystery of Edwin Drood

movies.description: This good old-fashioned horror yarn unwinds gratifyingly with Atwill reveling in the role of mad curator while Fay Wray demonstrates her credentials as scream queen of the early-talkies era.
movies.title: Mystery of the Wax Museum

movies.description: An extra helping of cheese offsets the better-than-average production values in this typical Karloff vehicle, which is really more of a detective mystery than anything resembling a horror film.
movies.title: Night Key

movies.description: A compelling atmosphere and a chilling murder scene provide an exquisite setup for what devolves into more of a psychological drama than a horror piece, betokening this story's roots as a stage play.
movies.title: Night Must Fall

movies.description: The only thing horrifying about this movie is the convoluted, nonsensical screenplay; although this is counterbalanced somewhat by the first-rate cast and some racy pre-code overtones.
movies.title: Night Nurse

movies.description: I have to admit I'm overrating this movie, but I love an old-fashioned spooky house mystery yarn with secret-panels, creeping villains and plenty of red-herring murder suspects like Lugosi's Degar; plus there's a freaky double-twist surprise ending.
movies.title: Night of Terror

movies.description: This ostensible murder mystery features dialogue rife with trademark Hitchcockian wit, a topsy turvy plot where nobody is who you think they are, and some crazy action sequences that take place on top of a moving train.
movies.title: Number Seventeen

movies.description: James Whale shows once again that he is the supreme master of cinematic horror in all its facets, from atmosphere to characterization to lighting effects; from comic timing to romantic interludes to action choreography.
movies.title: The Old Dark House

movies.description: From the ingenious opening credits you'll know that you're in for a gem of an old dark house mystery, and this one is a nicely-paced marvel peppered with all the accoutrements of the genre.
movies.title: One Frightened Night

movies.description: In the tradition of so many solidly crafted thrillers to come out of the U.K. in the years leading up to the war, this espionage parable maintains a brisk pace and thoroughly engages the viewer.
movies.title: Passenger to London

movies.description: Chalk up another entry in the category of "clever PI outwits bumbling cops to solve murder case, and gets girl in the process" (at least here Warner Brothers gives us a halfway compelling mystery to unravel).
movies.title: The Patient in Room 18

movies.description: An exceptional cast and sparkling writing distinguish this first entry in the RKO series about sharp-tongued schoolmarm detective Hildegarde Withers, and in  Ms. Oliver they found the perfect actress to lend just the right combination of primness and acerbity to the role.
movies.title: The Penguine Pool Murder

movies.description: The phantom creeps, alright, and so does this serial; through twelve chapters of repetitive tedium punctuated only by the vivacious Dorothy Arnold playing reporter Jean Drew.
movies.title: The Phantom Creeps (Serial)

movies.description: Novello certainly seems to have perfected his portrayal of the ripper (having played the same character in Hitchcock's 1920 silent The Lodger, on which this remake is based), because he brings a nice touch of melancholy to his performance.
movies.title: The Phantom Fiend

movies.description: A first-rate performance from Gordon Harker punctuates this genuinely intriguing British mystery from Gainsborough Pictures which features an abundance of eerie location shots of the Welsh countryside and coast.
movies.title: The Phantom Light

movies.description: Nicely executed murder mystery from RKO Pictures featuring some genuinely creepy moments and a well-concealed villain, along with the added attraction of its quintessentially pre-code subtext.
movies.title: The Phantom of Crestwood

movies.description: An intense early talkie from MGM based on a book by Gaston Leroux, this thriller is eminently watchable for the performances, despite such far-fetched antics as the wrongly-accused John Gilbert hiding in a cellar for four years before switching identities with the real killer.
movies.title: The Phantom of Paris

movies.description: Nicely crafted nautical mystery from England's Hammer Films, based on the case of the infamous ship Marie Celeste; unfortunately the continuity is heavily compromised in the edited U.S. version.
movies.title: Phantom Ship

movies.description: Dorothy Mackaill is a revelation as the sassy trollop with a heart of gold, and there are just sufficient thrilling moments to make this pre-code scintillator almost partially qualify as a horror flick.
movies.title: Picture Brides

movies.description: Lugosi is superb as the sadistic Dr. Vollin, and Karloff is smack dab in his element as the lowlife Bateman in this tale of revenge "suggested by" Poe's immortal poem, featuring what surely is the sole example of interpretive dance performed to a recitation of "The Raven".
movies.title: The Raven

movies.description: Production values are along the lines of a Gilligan's Island episode, and the story contains serious plot inconsistencies, but the sets are excellent (they reuse the massive wooden gates from King Kong), and Bela appears in one of his rare good guy roles.
movies.title: The Return of Chandu (Serial)

movies.description: Completely unrelated to the original Doctor X (except for the presence of an annoying wise-cracking reporter), this film features a worthy performance by Humphrey Bogart but is otherwise unremarkable.
movies.title: The Return of Doctor X

movies.description: This disjointed effort from the Halperin brothers provides a modicum of suspense when Jagger's character is on the verge of turning every last player into a zombie.
movies.title: Revolt of the Zombies

movies.description: The intriguing setup and chilling atmospherics of the initial scenes in the Lame Dog Inn of the title are wholly undermined by the preposterous shenanigans of the protagonist, a cub reporter whose brilliant idea is to frame himself for the crime.
movies.title: The Roadhouse Murder

movies.description: In this creaky detective spooker from Puritan Pictures a man and woman have their wedding plans disrupted by a series of murders at the Red Rock Tavern, with the evil deeds foretold by Joan Woodbury who provides the sole redeeming performance.
movies.title: The Rogues' Tavern

movies.description: You have to give Hitchcock some major props for daring in the 1930s to have an innocent schoolboy killed off in a terrorist attack on a bus; not to mention the spousal murder he has his heroine commit right before the happy ending.
movies.title: Sabotage

movies.description: Three suitors vie for a lady's affection by offering to each spend a night alone in the dreaded blue room in this atmospheric gem from Universal which has all the right elements for an old-house chiller.
movies.title: Secret of the Blue Room

movies.description: As much a melodrama as a whodunit, this early talkie from Columbia Pictures is elevated by the pre-code archness in Una Merkel's portrayal of the sympathetic love interest.
movies.title: The Secret Witness

movies.description: With an appealing cast, tight direction and a well-intentioned premise, this intriguing little mystery from Invincible Pictures nonetheless manages to strike a discordant final note with its preposterous ending.
movies.title: Secrets of Wu Sin

movies.description: Haven't we all suffered through enough of the wise-cracking amateur sleuth (in this case a novelist escaping to a secluded inn to write a mystery story) who outwits the crooks and makes the cops look like bumbling idiots?
movies.title: Seven Keys to Baldpate
Sexton Blake and the Hooded Terror

movies.description: In the horror genre there's really nothing quite as unwatchable as a misconceived comedy crossover, and this Warner Brothers travesty sets a new standard for the sheer obnoxiousness of its over-the-top harebrained slapstick.
movies.title: Sh! The Octopus

movies.description: Taking huge liberties with H. Rider Haggard's classic adventure novel, this Merian C. Cooper extravaganza falls a little flat despite its lavish sets and exotic locales.
movies.title: She

movies.description: Arthur Wontner turns in a creditable performance as the master sleuth, and the writers deliver a nice, taut, suspenseful storyline in this early talkie from England's Twickenham Studios.
movies.title: Sherlock Holmes' Fatal Hour

movies.description: From its horrific setup to its surprising conclusion, this unpretentious little low-budget campus murder mystery from Chesterfield Pictures is more engaging than most of its kind.
movies.title: A Shot in the Dark

movies.description: Some genuinely creepy atmosphere punctuates the first scene of this otherwise undistinguished British will-reading mystery centered around O.B. Clarence's crime-solving Reverend Makehan.
movies.title: Shot in the Dark

movies.description: The mediocre storyline of this murder mystery is offset by the Rogers' feisty rendition of a girl reporter in spirited rivalry with a leg man from another paper.
movies.title: A Shriek in the Night

movies.description: Despite an obviously meager budget, this rendition of the epic Sherlock Holmes tale manages to convey a real sense of dread, particularly in the person of the one-legged killer who most chillingly menaces Dr. Watson's future wife.
movies.title: The Sign of Four

movies.description: British mysteries of the era tend to offer more substance than this fluffy nonsense from the screenplay by Dorothy L. Sayers featuring her famous detective Lord Peter Wimsey.
movies.title: The Silent Passenger

movies.description: There's a reason you've never heard of Willis Kent Productions, and it has everything to do with uninspired and stiffly-acted features like this limp excuse for a murder mystery.
movies.title: Sinister Hands

movies.description: Lugosi as the hunchbacked Ygor is worth the price of admission by himself, but we're also treated to Karloff's final reprise of his role as the monster, Rathbone's stiff portrayal of the mad doctor's son, and Atwill's iconic Inspector Krogh (he of the trick hand).
movies.title: Son of Frankenstein

movies.description: This sequel possesses none of the grandeur of the original, with the scenes on Skull Island trading on hackneyed humor and claymation effects instead of ominousness and dread; and Helen Mack is cute, but she's certainly no Fay Wray.
movies.title: Son of Kong

movies.description: Atwill is at his menacing best in one of Monagram's more ambitious B offerings, but overall this picture suffers from the all-too-common malady of having a ridiculous plot.
movies.title: The Sphinx

movies.description: Yes, the premise of this Halperin Brothers mystery from Paramount is assuredly preposterous, but the film is redeemed by deft direction, moody atmosphere and pre-code Carole Lombard.
movies.title: Supernatural

movies.description: Brilliant overtones of German Expressionism, along with sharp dialog and stunning camera work distinguish this Gothic masterpiece, filmed when Barrymore was 49 years old and his leading lady Marian Marsh was just 17.
movies.title: Svengali

movies.description: Despite the occasionally humorous dialog, this film based on the Edgar Wallace play has a lackluster feel accentuated by a plot twist you can smell coming from midway through the first act.
movies.title: The Terror

movies.description: This overlooked gem from Paramount was well ahead of its time in its depiction of the horrific modus operandi employed by the murderer to carry out his evil deeds within the confines of a luxury pleasure yacht.
movies.title: Terror Aboard

movies.description: Fritz Lang uses sets and lighting brilliantly in this virtuosic example of German Expressionist filmmaking, delivering atmosphere galore in his banned last movie before fleeing the Nazis.
movies.title: The Testament of Dr. Mabuse

movies.description: This British noir thriller from Teddington Studios does an exceptional job of evoking pathos for its wrongly-accused man on the run, and to boot it features an especially compelling performance by the one and only Ernest Thesiger.
movies.title: They Drive by Night

movies.description: This starts off very promisingly in an old dark house where the master is murdered in plot with Eastern Indian overtones, but at the midpoint it loses its way somewhat and devolves into your basic gangster mystery.
movies.title: The Third Clue

movies.description: Built on a premise that probably paid off better in the novel, this RKO creaker gains a good measure of redemption thanks to a quintessential pre-code performance by Myrna Loy as the seductive villainess.
movies.title: Thirteen Women

movies.description: Typical of MGM horror in the thirties, this film exudes class and boasts a first-rate cast, but is ultimately flat and uninspiring with a strong penchant for implausibility.
movies.title: The Thirteenth Chair

movies.description: The masked killer contrives ingenious mechanisms for removing those who stand in his way.
movies.title: The Thirteenth Guest

movies.description: The best of Hitchcock's early features, with a truly thrilling series of chase sequences and a richly developed romantic interest; only slightly sullied by the ludicrous shenanigans during the last five minutes.
movies.title: The Thirty-Nine Steps

movies.description: With such a limited cast, this hoary old chestnut of a movie would have trouble enough maintaining suspense as to the culprit's identity; even without packing in so many dead giveaways.
movies.title: Tomorrow at Seven

movies.description: What could go wrong when a crazy surgeon on the lamb for performing dangerous experiments hires a boat and fills it with desperate criminals who are willing to be guinea pigs since their alternative on land is certain execution?
movies.title: Torture Ship

movies.description: Basil Rathbone and Boris Karloff team up as Richard III and his henchman Mord in this horror piece masquerading as historical drama.
movies.title: Tower of London

movies.description: As you'd expect from MGM, this picture is well-acted with snappy dialog and impeccable production values; however, the outrageous contrivances in the central premise make it hard to muster much sympathy for Ms. Young's predicament.
movies.title: The Unguarded Hour

movies.description: Chaney's first talkie was sadly his final movie and unfortunately not a very good one, mostly due to a lack of any really menacing villains, although Chaney as always delivers a performance teeming with complexity and pathos.
movies.title: The Unholy Three

movies.description: Strayer assembled a truly stellar cast for this chiller in the classical mold, replete with standout performances including good-old Lionel Atwill as the crazy doctor and Dwight Frye as the village idiot slash red herring.
movies.title: The Vampire Bat

movies.description: The chilling potential of the vampire legend is fully realized in this mostly-silent German piece invested with genuinely horrifying sequences revealed through the prism of Dreyer's fantastic vision.
movies.title: Vampyr

movies.description: This is an utterly forgettable offering from tiny, unprolific Chadwick Productions, packed with all the cliches and none of the charm of so many other early-talkie drawing room murder mysteries.
movies.title: The Wayne Murder Case

movies.description: A bizarre variation on the werewolf mythology is presented in this Universal thriller which predates the iconic Lon Chaney Jr. vehicle by six years and builds up to a similarly tragic denouement,
movies.title: Werewolf of London

movies.description: The biggest mystery in this Warner Brothers B-level programmer is how astrology somehow became an ancient Oriental practice; nonetheless Ms. Wong acquits herself nicely as the heroine who must solve a murder to clear her name.
movies.title: When Were You Born

movies.description: The earliest and best of the Nurse Sarah Keate mysteries from Warner Brothers, this well-executed programmer distinguishes itself with a plausible story line and an intelligent cast.
movies.title: While the Patient Slept

movies.description: First-rate stunts and action sequences set this apart from the usual low-budget movie serial fare; however Lugosi is ill-used in the role of Professor Strang, and the plot suffers from some highly repetitive back-and-forth possession of the stolen jewels.
movies.title: The Whispering Shadow (Serial)

movies.description: MGM delivers a nifty, suspenseful pre-code crime drama, which benefits greatly from the studio's lofty production values and especially its stable of eminent character actors.
movies.title: Whistling in the Dark

movies.description: Outstanding atmosphere distinguishes this murder mystery from Warner Brothers, although otherwise it suffers from the standard time-worn shenanigans typical of the whodunit genre.
movies.title: The White Cockatoo

movies.description: The Halperin brothers and writer Garnett Weston conceived a devilishly twisted plotline beset by stagey histrionics from the cast; still, Lugosi's glowering portrayal of the demented zombie-lord Legendre along with some kick-ass sets on loan from Universal make this movie well worthwhile.
movies.title: White Zombie

movies.description: For some unfathomable reason James Whale agreed to remake his excellent "Kiss Before the Mirror" (only five years after the original, but with the all-important Motion Picture Production Code installed in the meantime), and the censors can't be blamed entirely for the bombastic yet inneffectual result.
movies.title: Wives Under Suspicion

movies.description: A well-acted dark crime drama filmed at Biograph Studios in the Bronx featuring a sultry performance from Fay Wray and a despicable villain in Melvyn Douglass.
movies.title: Woman in the Shadows
The Case of the Howling Dog
